document.masterDocTitle: The larva of Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972 (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae), including a key to the larvae of Glossosomatidae of the Hellenic western Balkan region

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The larva of Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972 (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae), including a key to the larvae of Glossosomatidae of the Hellenic western Balkan region

heading.emphasis:
Description of the final instar larva of
Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972

subSubSection.paragraph: Biometry. Body length ranging from 3.2 to 3.9 mm , head width from 0.37 to 0.40 mm (n = 8).

Abdomen. Abdominal segments I–VIII without sclerites. As typical for “Spicipalpia”, abdominal segment I without fleshy protuberances. Sternum II with pair of patches of microscopic spines ( Fig. 9 ) as described by Craft & Morse (1997) . Dorsal setation of abdominal segments consisting of 3 pairs of setae: anteromedian, posteromedian, and lateral paired setae ( sa 1, sa 2, and sa 3, respectively, of Wiggins 1996 ), with 1 anteromedian and 1 posteromedian setal pair on each of terga I–VIII, 2 pairs of lateral setae on terga I and VIII, 1 pair of lateral setae on tergum II and 2 pairs of tiny pale setae medially of each median lateral seta on tergum VIII ( Fig. 12 ss). Each abdominal segment with 1 pair of ventrolateral setae except on segments VI and VII ( Figs. 9 vs, 10vs). Gills and lateral fringe lacking. Dorsal sclerite of abdominal segment IX medium brown, trapezoidal, its crenulate posterior margin with 8 setae of almost equal length, including pair of outermost setae ( Fig. 12 , arrow); pair of smaller setae also present. Proximal sections of anal prolegs broadly joined with segment IX, their lateral sclerites medium brown, rectangular, each with 4 long, black apicodorsal setae (1 seta broken in Fig. 11 ); distal section free from abdomen, leg-like, ventral sole plate ( Wiggins 1996 ) light brown ( Fig. 11 ). Anal claws dark brown, each with 2 tiny dorsal accessory hooks ( Figs. 10, 11 ). As typical for Agapetinae ( Wiggins 1996 ), anal opening without pair of vertical sclerotized bars along each side ( Fig. 11 ), but with anal papillae ( Fig. 11 ap).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 7–13.
Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972
, final instar larva. 7 , left hind leg, posterior face; 8 , thorax, ventral (ms = mesosternal sclerite, ps = prosternal sclerite); 9 , metathorax and abdominal segments I–IV, right ventrolateral (ls = lateral seta, vs = ventral seta); 10 , abdominal segments IV–IX, right lateral (vs = ventral seta); 11 , posterior tip of abdomen, right posterolateral (ap = anal papillae). 12 , posterior tip of abdomen, dorsal (arrow = left posterolateral seta on tergite IX; ss= alveolae of tiny pair of pale setae); 13 , larval case, ventral. Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Larval case. Tortoise-shaped, with flat ventral transverse strap (‘plastron’ sensu Wiggins 1996 ) and convex dorsal outline, 4.5 to 5.5 mm long, 1.9 to 3.6 mm wide, and 1.4 to 1.8 mm high (n = 8). Ventrally, with two openings near anterior and posterior border which can be shut by hinged closures consisting of mineral particles and silk ( Fig. 13 ). Cases made of mineral particles of mixed size ( Figs. 13–15 ).

heading.emphasis:
Morphological diagnosis of fifth instar larvae of
Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972
from those of other

subSubSection.paragraph: A summary of morphological features for the identification of European caddisfly families was given by Waringer & Graf (2013) . Within the framework of the key for larvae of Trichoptera families by Pitsch (1993) and Waringer & Graf (2011) , glossosomatid larvae are separable from those of other families by possessing the following features: - with transportable case shaped like a turtle shell ( Figs. 13 , 20 ); - labrum sclerotized ( Fig. 1 );

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–19. Glossosomatidae genn. spp., final instar larvae. 14–15 ,
Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972: 14
, larval case, dorsal; 15 , larval case, lateral. 16–17 .
Glossosoma conforme Neboiss 1963: 16
, thorax, dorsal (p = pronotum); 17 , posterior tip of abdomen, right lateral (arrow = left lateral seta on abdominal tergite IX). 18 ,
Glossosoma bifidum McLachlan 1879
, posterior tip of abdomen, right lateral (arrow = left lateral seta on abdominal tergite IX). 19 ,
Synagapetus iridipennis McLachlan 1879
, abdominal segments I–IV, right lateral (ls = lateral seta). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
In the context of the Glossosomatid larvae of European Ecoregion 6 (Hellenic western Balkan region),
Agapetus episkopi
belongs to subfamily Agapetinae where the pronotum is completely sclerotized and covered by two plates in close median contact ( Fig. 4p ); meso- and metanota are incompletely sclerotized and each bearing only two small sclerites (
Figs. 4s, 4t
). Within Agapetinae , the dorsal case profile is rounded in
A. episkopi
, and a sand collar is not attached to its base ( Figs. 14, 15 ), as it is common in genus
Synagapetus
( Fig. 20 ). Therefore,
A. episkopi
keys together with
Agapetus laniger
and
A. delicatulus
, and can easily be separated from the latter two because
A. episkopi
( Figs. 1, 2 ) lacks the pale area on the frontoclypeus of those species and the pale posterior sections of the parietalia of
A . laniger
(Fig. 21).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 20. Glossosomatidae genn. spp., final instar larvae. 20 ,
Synagapetus iridipennis McLachlan 1879
, larval case, ventral (arrows = collar of sand grains). 21 ,
Agapetus
laniger Pictet
1834
, head, frontal (a = pale central patch on frontoclypeus, b = pale patches on posterior sections of parietalia). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

heading.emphasis:
Key to the hitherto known final instar
Agapetus
larvae of European Ecoregion 6

paragraph.keyLead:
2 Lateral pair of setae (setae 1a of Waringer & Graf 2011 ) on dorsal sclerite of abdominal tergum IX originating at posterior margin and almost as long as other setae along posterior margin of this sclerite ( Fig. 17 , arrow) ...................................................................................................
Glossosoma conforme Neboiss 1963

- Lateral pair of setae on dorsal sclerite of abdominal segment IX distinctly set anterior of posterior margin and significantly shorter than other setae along posterior margin of this sclerite ( Fig. 18 , arrow).......
Glossosoma bifidum McLachlan 1879

3 With one lateral seta on each side of abdominal tergum III ( Fig. 19 ls); case with sand collars ( Fig. 20 )......................................................................................
Synagapetus iridipennis McLachlan 1879

4 With two lateral setae (ls) on each side of abdominal tergum I ( Fig. 9 ls); frontoclypeus without pale central area ( Fig. 1 )..............................................................................
Agapetus episkopi Malicky 1972

5 Posterior sections of parietalia with pale areas (Fig. 21b); lateral setae on abdominal tergite IX almost as long as other setae along posterior margin of this sclerite (as in Fig. 12 , arrow)..............................
Agapetus laniger Pictet 1834

- Posterior sections of parietalia without pale areas; lateral setae on abdominal tergite IX distinctly shorter than other setae along posterior margin of this sclerite (as in Fig. 18 , arrow)..........................
Agapetus delicatulus McLachlan 1884

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ecology and distribution.
Agapetus episkopi
is found on most islands of the Aegean Sea, including Crete , Euboea, Andros, Tinos, Kea, Naxos, Ikaria, Skiathos, Skopelos, Chios, and Samos ( Malicky 2005b , 2014 ). There are only two records from the coast of the mainland: Monemvasia (southern Peloponnese ) and Platamonas (northern Greece ). The species is also widespread in the western part of Turkey ( Sipahiler 2008 ).

In Crete , adults can be found all year round with four emergence maxima, the highest being in May–June and September–October ( Malicky 2005b ). On Serifos,
A. episkopi
is on the wing during May–June, although a longer flight activity is expected.
Agapetus episkopi
is sympatric with
Hydroptila aegyptia Ulmer 1963
,
H. kalonichtis Malicky 1972
,
H. vectis Curtis 1834
,
Oxyethira falcata Morton 1893
,
Hydropsyche pygmalion Malicky 2001
,
Polycentropus ierapetra Malicky 1972
,
Tinodes horstaspoecki Malicky 1975
(in Kumanski & Malicky 1975 ),
T. serifos Malicky 1984
, and
Wormaldia subnigra McLachlan 1865
.
